questions.ocrQuestion:
Which of the following functions represents acceptable realistic wave function of a bound state of the particle in the range \( (-\infty < x < \infty) \) ? \( (A, B, D, E, F \) are positive real constants \( \& C \) is negative real constant \( ) \)
(a) \( \varphi(x)=A \tan x \)
(b) \( \varphi(x)=B \cos x \)
(c) \( \varphi(x)=C \exp \left(-D / x^{2}\right) \)
(d) \( \varphi(x)=E x \exp \left(-F x^{2}\right) \)
questions.onlyq_text: Which of the following functions represents acceptable realistic wave function of a bound state of the particle in the range \( (-\infty < x < \infty) \) ? \( (A, B, D, E, F \) are positive real constants \( \& C \) is negative real constant \( ) \)
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Which of the following is an allowed wavefunction for a particle in a bound state? (where \( N \) is a constant and \( \alpha, \beta>0 \) )
(a) \( \psi(x)=N \frac{e^{-\alpha x}}{x^{3}} \)
(b) \( \psi(x)=N\left(1-e^{-\alpha x}\right) \)
(c) \( \psi(x)=N e^{-\alpha x} e^{-\beta\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)} \)
(d) \( \psi(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}\text { non-zero constant } & \text { if } x < R \\ 0 & \text { if } x>R\end{array}\right. \)
questions.onlyq_text: Which of the following is an allowed wavefunction for a particle in a bound state? (where \( N \) is a constant and \( \alpha, \beta>0 \) )

options.option: (d) \( \psi(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}\text { non-zero constant } & \text { if } x < R \\ 0 & \text { if } x>R\end{array}\right. \)

questions.ocrQuestion:
Which of the following wave function is an allowed wavefunction for a particle in a bound state for all values of \( x \) ? (A is a real constant)
(a) \( \psi(x)=A \sec x \)
(b) \( \psi(x)=A \tan x \)
(c) \( \psi(x)=A e^{x^{2}} \)
(d) \( \psi(x)=A e^{-x^{2}} \)
questions.onlyq_text: Which of the following wave function is an allowed wavefunction for a particle in a bound state for all values of \( x \) ? (A is a real constant)

questions.ocrQuestion:
An one dimensional wave function is given by
\[
\psi(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
A \sin \left(\frac{\pi x}{2 l}\right) ; & 0 < x < 2 l \\
0 & ; \quad \text { otherwise }
\end{array}\right\}
\]

The value of the normalization constant ' \( A \) ' is
(a) \( \sqrt{1 / l} \)
(b) \( \sqrt{2 / 3 l} \)
(c) \( \sqrt{2 / l} \)
(d) \( \sqrt{1 / 3 l} \)

questions.ocrQuestion:
In an one-dimensional system, the normalized wave function is given by
\[
\psi(x)=N \exp [-\alpha|x|] \quad(\alpha \text { is positive real constant })
\]
where \( N \) is normalization constant. What is the value of \( N \) ?
(a) \( \sqrt{2 / \alpha} \)
(b) \( \sqrt{2 \alpha} \)
(c) \( \sqrt{1 / \alpha} \)
(d) \( \sqrt{\alpha} \)
questions.onlyq_text: In an one-dimensional system, the normalized wave function is given by\[\psi(x)=N \exp [-\alpha|x|] \quad(\alpha \text { is positive real constant })\]where \( N \) is normalization constant. What is the value of \( N \) ?
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The wave function of a particle at a certain time is given as following:
\[
\psi(x)=\frac{A}{\sqrt{x^{2}+a^{2}}} e^{i k x}[a, k \text { are positive real constants }]
\]

The real value of \(A\) such that \(\psi(x)\) is normalized, is
(a) \(\frac{a}{\pi}\)
(b) \(\sqrt{\frac{a}{\pi}}\)
(c) \(\sqrt{\frac{2 a}{\pi}}\)
(d) \(\sqrt{\frac{a}{2 \pi}}\)
questions.onlyq_text: The wave function of a particle at a certain time is given as following: \[ \psi(x)=\frac{A}{\sqrt{x^{2}+a^{2}}} e^{i k x}[a, k \text { are positive real constants }] \] The real value of \(A\) such that \(\psi(x)\) is normalized, is

solutions.sol_html:
for normalized wave function 

\[ \begin{aligned} & \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*}(x) \psi(x) d x=1 \\ \Rightarrow & \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{A^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)} e^{i k x} e^{-i k x} d x=1 \\ \Rightarrow & {A^{2}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^{2}+a^{2}} d x=1 \\ \Rightarrow & A^{2} \frac{\pi}{a}=1 \quad\left[\therefore \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^{2}+a^{2}} d x=\frac{\pi}{a}\right] \\ \Rightarrow & A=\sqrt{\frac{a}{\pi}} \end{aligned} \]

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Which of the following wave function is an allowed wavefunction for a particle in a bound state for all values of \(x\) ? (A is a real constant)
(a) \(\psi(x)=A \exp \left[-\frac{|x|}{a}+i k x\right]\)
(b) \(\psi(x)=A \exp \left[\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}+i k x\right]\)
(c) \(\psi(x)=A \frac{\sin k x}{x^{2}}\)
(d) \(\psi(x)=A \exp \left[-\frac{|x|}{a}\right]\)
questions.onlyq_text: Which of the following wave function is an allowed wavefunction for a particle in a bound state for all values of \(x\) ? (A is a real constant)
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The wave function of a particle, constraint to move along \(x\) axis at certain instant of time is given as
\[
\psi(x)=A \exp \left[-\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}+i b x\right][a, b \text { are positive real constants }]
\]

The normalization constant ' \(A\) ' is
(a) \(\sqrt{\frac{\sqrt{2}}{a \sqrt{\pi}}}\)
(b) \(\sqrt{\frac{2 \sqrt{2}}{a \sqrt{\pi}}}\)
(c) \(\frac{2 \sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{\pi a}}\)
(d) \(\frac{2 \sqrt{2}}{a \sqrt{\pi}}\)
questions.onlyq_text: The wave function of a particle, constraint to move along \(x\) axis at certain instant of time is given as \[ \psi(x)=A \exp \left[-\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}+i b x\right][a, b \text { are positive real constants }] \] The normalization constant ' \(A\) ' is

solutions.sol_html: \(\begin{array}{l} \text { Given, } \Psi(x)=A \exp \left[-\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}+i b x\right] \\ \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*}{(x)}  \psi(x) d x=1 \quad(\text { Normalization condition) } \\ \Rightarrow A^{2} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-2 \frac{ x^{2}}{a^{2}}} d x=1 \\ \Rightarrow 2 A^{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{\frac{-2 x^{2}}{a^{2}}} d x=1 \quad\left(\therefore e^{-\frac{2 x^{2}}{a^{2}}} \text { is an even function) }\right. \\ \Rightarrow2A^2\times\frac12\frac{\Gamma\left(\frac{0+1}2\right)}{\left(\alpha\right)^\frac{o+1}2}=1\quad\left(\therefore\int_0^\infty x^ne^{-\alpha x^2}dx=\frac12\frac{\Gamma\left(\frac{n+1}2\right)}{\left(\alpha\right)^\frac{n+1}2}\right) \\ \Rightarrow A^{2} \frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{\sqrt{2}} a=1 \\ \Rightarrow A=\sqrt{\frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{\pi} a}}\end{array}\)

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The normalized wave function of the particle is given as following:
\[
\psi(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
C\left(1-x^{2}\right) & \text { for }-1 \leq x \leq 1 \\
0 & \text { otherwise }
\end{array}\right.
\]

The value of the constant \(C\) is
(a) \(\sqrt{15} / 4\)
(b) \(\sqrt{15} / 2\)
(c) \(\sqrt{15} / 8\)
(d) \(\sqrt{2 / 3}\)
questions.onlyq_text: The normalized wave function of the particle is given as following: \[ \psi(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll} C\left(1-x^{2}\right) & \text { for }-1 \leq x \leq 1 \\ 0 & \text { otherwise } \end{array}\right. \] The value of the constant \(C\) is

solutions.sol_html:
\(\psi\) is normalized

\[ \begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*} \psi d x=1 \\ \Rightarrow & \int_{-1}^{1} c^{2}\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{2} d x=1 \\ \Rightarrow & c^{2} \int_{-1}^{1}\left(1+x^{4}-2 x^{2}\right) d x=1 \\ \Rightarrow & c^{2}\left[x+\frac{x^{5}}{5}-\frac{2}{3} x^{3}\right]_{-1}^{1}=1 \\ \Rightarrow & c^{2}\left(1+\frac{1}{5}-\frac{2}{3}+1+\frac{1}{5}-\frac{2}{3}\right)=1 \\ \Rightarrow & c^{2} \times \frac{16}{15}=1 \\ \Rightarrow & c=\frac{\sqrt{15}}{4} \end{aligned} \]

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
A one dimensional wave function corresponding to a particle is given by
\[
\psi(x)=\sqrt{a} e^{-a|x|}[a \text { are positive real constant }]
\]

The probability of finding the particle between \(x=1 / \mathrm{a}\) to \(x=2 / \mathrm{a}\) is equal to
(a) \(e^{-2}-e^{-4}\)
(b) \(\frac{e^{-2}-e^{-4}}{2}\)
(c) \(\frac{e^{-2}-e^{-4}}{4}\)
(d) \(\frac{e^{-2}+e^{-4}}{4}\)
questions.onlyq_text: A one dimensional wave function corresponding to a particle is given by \[ \psi(x)=\sqrt{a} e^{-a|x|}[a \text { are positive real constant }] \] The probability of finding the particle between \(x=1 / \mathrm{a}\) to \(x=2 / \mathrm{a}\) is equal to

solutions.sol_html:
Given, \(\psi(x)=\sqrt{a} e^{-a|x|}\)

Probability of finding the particle between \(x=\frac{1}{a}\) to \(x=\frac{2}{a}\) is 

\[ \begin{aligned} P & =\int_{1 / a}^{2 / a} \psi^{*} \psi d x \\ & =a \int_{1 / a}^{2 / a} e^{-2 a(x)} d x \\ & =\frac{a}{-2 a}\left[e^{-2 a x}\right]_{1 / a}^{2 / a} \\ & =-\frac{1}{2}\left[e^{-2 a \times \frac{2}{a}}-e^{-2 a \times \frac{1}{a}}\right] \\ & =-\frac{1}{2}\left[e^{-4}-e^{-2}\right] \\ P & =\frac{e^{-2}-e^{-4}}{2} \end{aligned} \]

questions.subject: PHYSICS
